body: This would probably be better as an option instead of something that happens by default. There are situations in which the current behaviour is desirable.

I think this would mostly give a sense of false security. You can obviously block the device from talking to you any more, and it could be wise to let the introducer inform the other members of the cluster that the device should no longer be considered valid. But the files that have been shared are already on the remote device, and attempting to remove them is not guaranteed to succeed. Am I understanding what you're asking for?

Yeah, I'm not sure I understand this either.
I can see the requirement to propagate the removal of a device from the introducer to his trusting nodes (use case: company mesh like @Rewt0r mentioned; one device leaves for whatever reason and I don't want to manually remove the device from all nodes), too, but this has nothing to do with shares. And please let's not have this discussion about a killswitch in sync software again (I've had enough fruitless arguments on the BTSync forums) - it's trivial to circumvent and only gives you a sense of false security, like @calmh said.

Yes I am requesting that an Introducer can instruct a device to remove its share as well as remove other devices. If for whatever reason there's a problem with config and we delete the config and start again, the device id changes so we update this in our introducer and remove the old one but all other devices keep the deleted device in their list.
I get the "remove devices from other places when removed on the introducer", but I'm not sure I get the "remove the share" part.

What don't you get about it? By share I mean Folder

EDIT: This part isn't a MASSIVE deal it'd just be nice - that way if a device is lost or stolen or someone that was using a personal device leaves the company the Introducer could request that the device deletes any folders that it introduced.

As I was writing my edit it became apparent that you would have no easy way of implementing this unless Introducers could also Introduce Folders. That way the Introducer could instruct the device being removed to delete any Folders introduced by this Introducer
What's the point in removing the share if the device won't sync anymore anyway, because it was removed from all cluster nodes?
Because it still has a copy? That could be sensitive data

Aaand here we are with the killswitch discussion.

If it's sensitive data, don't give it out. If you do give it out, you can't make sure it won't be copied somewhere else by technical means.
Don't you have clauses in your contracts that forbid abusing and/or distributing sensitive data? You can't enforce this by software on a device that is not under your control at all times (and even if it was, you can't rely on it).

Have you ever worked in a company that uses the cloud for their files rather than the old share connected to a domain controller?

I know Syncthing isn't the cloud per se. But the issue still remains. Of course most if not all contracts contain these sort of clauses, but what if on the other hand the device was lost or stolen and happens to come online without being wiped? Dropbox even implemented this: https://www.dropbox.com/help/4227

You can already do this.
Move all the content out of the folder (apart from the .stfolder file), causing all nodes to accept the delete leaving the compromised node attached (but perhaps everybody sets master mode not to accept any updates from the compromised node), and then re-establish a new network without the compromised device, and reshare the files.

> Have you ever worked in a company that uses the cloud for their files rather than the old share connected to a domain controller?

No I haven't, for precisely that reason. We don't allow BYOD, either.

For lost or stolen devices, use full disk encryption. For malicous employees, use the law.
Killswitches only work against very stupid thieves.

That sounds like a good solution @AudriusButkevicius but it would be so much easier if there was some sort of automatic process. That way I'd have to connect to all devices to tell them that their folder is master  before doing so and is a lot of effort every time

@StrikerTwo but that still isn't a solution. Granted Syncthing isn't even v1 yet but this won't be the first time this comes up. As businesses start moving onto it the question will come up more and more

Deleting all files is not a very elegant solution IMHO and could lead to data loss if someone has a local change that has not synced back to the master when the delete command arrives.

@Rewt0r I'd rather have no technical solution than a half-assed one I can't rely on because it only works if the target cooperates. YMMV.

I don't see how it could cause that sort of issue?

From the Introducer -> Delete Device -> Introducer Removes Device (removing any chance that this device can sync with deleted files) -> Introducer Send Delete Packet -> Introducer Send Remove Device ID packet to all other devices

I meant the workaround @AudriusButkevicius proposed with methods already available. Your proposal would of couse not lead to (unintentional) data loss. But you still have to rely on the (potentially malicious) target to cooporate.
